question: Where does authority and invariant drift appear across canonical and derivative protocol files?
method: Built drift_scanner.py to extract 14 required protocol blocks from SWARM.md/CORE.md, then check all 6 bridge files for presence. Also check MSC section sync and version-tracking metadata.
expect: Scanner identifies >=3 requirement gaps between canonical and derivative files
actual: Scanner found 2 drift categories: 1 HIGH (node-interaction missing from 4/6 bridges, ~260 sessions undetected), 5 LOW (version-tracking absent from 5/6 bridges). MSC sections 100% synchronized — no divergence. After fix: 0 HIGH drifts, coverage 89.9%→94.4%.
diff: Expected >=3 gaps, found 2 categories (1 HIGH + 1 LOW). The HIGH drift was more severe than expected (~260 sessions), but fewer categories than predicted. MSC sync was better than expected (100% identical). The tool is more valuable as ongoing monitor than one-shot audit.

findings.description: Node interaction (minimum-by-default) block missing from .cursorrules, GEMINI.md, .windsurfrules, .github/copilot-instructions.md
No version/sync metadata in 5/6 bridge files (CLAUDE.md has claude_md_version)

isomorphism: ISO-13 anti-windup: intake (new guidance added to one bridge) without processing (propagation to all bridges) = indefinite queue growth. Same mechanism as challenge throughput (F-GOV3) and experiment harvest (L-574).
next_steps: Wire drift_scanner.py into periodic maintenance (check.sh or maintenance.py)
Add bridge_sync_version metadata to all bridge files (LOW priority)
Measure drift recurrence rate over next 10 sessions
